page.title: 08Ecology of Blithfield
page.content: The area is mostly intensively managed grassland with some rough grazing. Cereal crops are grown mostly on the east side of the Admaston-Rugeley road. the area supports beef and dairy herds of cows mainly of the Fresian breed. Sheep gaze the verges of the reservoir. The hedges to th fields are well maintained and are mainly of hawthorn, field maple and elm with a small amount of lackthorn, damson, elder and a few crab apples. Trees grown in the hedes are mostly oak, this being the dominant tree, ash and a few willow and sycamore. In the rough razing dandelions, buttercups, clover, dock and thistles appear in their due season. The river Blythe flows out of the reservoir and along this valley alders and willows grow.
